title: 115_s2516
content: The Act may be cited as the "Alternatives to Opioids (ALTO) in the Emergency Department Act". The Congress finds that opioids caused over 42,000 deaths in 2016, with 40% involving prescription opioids. The economic burden of prescription opioid misuse is $78.5 billion annually. Over 200 million opioid prescriptions are written each year, leading to 2 million Americans with substance use disorder symptoms. 21-29% of chronic pain patients misuse opioids. Emergency departments in several States have developed innovative programs to utilize non-opioid pain treatments and reduce opioid use. SEC. 3. EMERGENCY DEPARTMENT ALTERNATIVES TO OPIOIDS DEMONSTRATION PROGRAM. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a 3-year demonstration program awarding grants to hospitals and emergency departments to develop alternative pain management protocols limiting opioid use. Eligible facilities must apply for grants, and geographical diversity among recipients will be considered. The Secretary will ensure geographical diversity among grant recipients. Grants will be used to target common painful conditions, train providers on limited opioid use, collect data, and provide alternatives to opioids for patients with painful conditions. The Secretary offers technical support to grant recipients for alternative pain management protocols and treatments, including non-opioid medications and non-medication options for common painful conditions. The grant recipients must provide annual evaluations to the Secretary, detailing the progress of the program funded through the grant, including descriptions of alternative pain management protocols and treatments used. The grant recipients must provide annual evaluations to the Secretary, detailing the progress of the program funded through the grant, including descriptions of alternative pain management protocols and treatments used. Data on the alternative pain management protocols and treatments employed, conditions treated, and patients' self-reported pain ratings before and after treatment are also required. Additionally, information on opioid prescriptions written during different stages of the program is necessary. The data required for evaluation includes patients' demographics, conditions for opioid prescriptions, self-reported pain ratings, use of alternative pain management protocols, transition to inpatient care, and post-protocol opioid prescriptions. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress on the results of the demonstration program, including the number of applications received and funded, evaluations of pain management protocols, and recommendations for broader implementation to limit opioid use in emergency departments. Authorization of appropriations is required to carry out this section. Authorization of Appropriations: $10,000,000 authorized for each fiscal year from 2019 to 2021.
